conclusion: To determine the ratio \(\frac{\varepsilon'}{\varepsilon}\), we need to analyze the induced electromotive force (emf) in both configurations of the rod.
There is a straight metal rod moving perpendicularly to a uniform magnetic field.

premise: The straight rod moves perpendicularly to the magnetic field \(\mathbf{B}\).
conclusion: The induced emf \(\varepsilon\) is given by \(\varepsilon = B \cdot L \cdot v\).
The rod is bent into two equal-length segments at a right angle and placed in the magnetic field.

premise: Each segment of the bent rod has a length \(L/2\).
conclusion: The rod moves along the angle bisector with velocity \(v\).

premise: The velocity \(v\) can be resolved into two perpendicular components along each segment.
Each segment has a length \(L/2\) and velocity component \(v/\sqrt{2}\).
conclusion: The induced emf in each segment is \(\varepsilon_{\text{segment}} = B \cdot \left(\frac{L}{2}\right) \cdot \left(\frac{v}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\).

premise: There are two segments with induced emf \(\varepsilon_{\text{segment}}\).
conclusion: The total induced emf \(\varepsilon'\) is \(2 \cdot \varepsilon_{\text{segment}} = B \cdot L \cdot v \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\).

premise: The total induced emf \(\varepsilon'\) is \(B \cdot L \cdot v \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\) and \(\varepsilon = B \cdot L \cdot v\).
